sentences.sentence: “And now,” said Aslan, “Narnia is established( 建立 ). We must next take thought for keeping it safe.
I will call some of you to my council.
Come hither( 到这里 ) to me, you the chief Dwarf( 小矮人 ), and you the River-god, and you Oak( 橡树 ) and the He-Owl( 猫头鹰 ), and both the Ravens( 乌鸦 ) and the Bull-Elephant( 公象 ).
We must talk together. For though the world is not five hours old an evil( 恶魔 ) has already entered it.”
The creatures he had named came forward and he turned away eastward( 向东 ) with them.
The others all began talking, saying things like “What did he say had entered the world?—A Neevil—What’s a Neevil?—No, he didn’t say a Neevil, he said a weevil—Well, what’s that?”
“Look here,” said Digory to Polly, “I’ve got to go after him—Aslan, I mean, the Lion. I must speak to him.”
“Do you think we can?” said Polly. “I wouldn’t dare.”
“I’ve got to,” said Digory. “It’s about Mother. If anyone could give me something that would do her good, it would be him.”
“I’ll come along with you,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “I liked the looks of him. And I don’t reckon( 认为 ) these other beasts will go for us. And I want a word with old Strawberry.”
So all three of them stepped out boldly( 大胆地 )—or as boldly( 大胆地 ) as they could—toward the assembly( 集会 ) of animals.
The creatures were so busy talking to one another and making friends that they didn’t notice the three humans until they were very close;
nor did they hear Uncle Andrew,
who was standing trembling( 颤抖 ) in his buttoned boots a good way off and shouting (but by no means at the top of his voice).
“Digory! Come back! Come back at once when you’re told. I forbid( 不允许 ) you to go a step further.”
When at last they were right in among the animals, the animals all stopped talking and stared at them.
“Well?” said the He-Beaver( 海狸 ) at last, “what, in the name of Aslan, are these?”
“Please,” began Digory in a rather breathless voice, when a Rabbit said, “They’re a kind of large lettuce( 莴苣 ), that’s my belief.”
“No, we’re not, honestly we’re not,” said Polly hastily( 飞快地 ). “We’re not at all nice to eat.”
“There!” said the Mole. “They can talk. Who ever heard of a talking lettuce( 莴苣 )?”
“Perhaps they’re the second joke,” suggested the Jackdaw( 寒鸦 ).
A Panther( 黑豹 ), which had been washing its face, stopped for a moment to say, “Well, if they are, they’re nothing like so good as the first one.
At least, I don’t see anything very funny about them.” It yawned( 打呵欠 ) and went on with its wash.
“Oh, please,” said Digory. “I’m in such a hurry. I want to see the Lion.”
All this time the Cabby( 马车夫 ) had been trying to catch Strawberry’s eye. Now he did.
“Now, Strawberry, old boy,” he said. “You know me.
You aren’t going to stand there and say as you don’t know me.”
“What’s the Thing talking about, Horse?” said several voices.
“Well,” said Strawberry very slowly, “I don’t exactly know, I think most of us don’t know much about anything yet.
But I’ve a sort of idea I’ve seen a thing like this before.
I’ve a feeling I lived somewhere else—or was something else—before Aslan woke us all up a few minutes ago.
It’s all very muddled( 混乱的 ). Like a dream.
But there were things like these three in the dream.”
“What?” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “Don't know me? Didn't I used to bring you a hot mash( 饲料 ) on an evening when you were out of sorts?
Didn't I rub( 顺毛 ) you down proper?
Did I ever forget to put your cloth on you if you were standing in the cold?
I wouldn’t have thought it of you, Strawberry.”
“It does begin to come back,” said the Horse thoughtfully. “Yes. Let me think now, let me think.
Yes, you used to tie a horrid( 极讨厌的 ) black thing behind me and then hit me to make me run,
and however far I ran this black thing would always be coming rattle-rattle( 喀哒喀哒 ) behind me.”
“We had our living to earn, you see,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “Yours the same as mine.
And if there hadn’t been a work and a whip( 鞭子 ) there wouldn't have been a stable( 马厩 ), or any hay( 干草 ), or mash( 饲料 ), or oats( 燕麦 ).
For you did get a taste of oats( 燕麦 ) when I could afford them, which no one can deny( 否认 ).”
“Oats( 燕麦 )?” said the Horse, pricking up( 竖起 ) his ears. “Yes, I remember something about that.
Yes, I remember more and more. You were always sitting up somewhere behind,
and I was always running in front, pulling you and the black thing. I know I did all the work.”
“In summer, that'd be true,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “Hot work for you and a cool seat for me.
But what about winter, old boy, when you were keeping yourself warm and I was sitting up there with my feet like ice and my nose fair pinched( 吹掉 ) off me with the wind,
and my hands that numb( 麻木的 ) I couldn’t hardly hold the reins( 缰绳 )?”
“It was a hard, cruel country,” said Strawberry. “There was no grass. All hard stones.”
“Too true, mate( 伙伴 ), too true!” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “A hard world it was.
I always did say those paving-stones( 铺路石 ) weren’t fair on any horse.
That’s London, that is. I didn’t like it no more than what you did.
You were a country horse, and I was a country man.
Used to sing in the choir( 唱诗班 ), I did, down at home. But there wasn’t a living for me there.”
“Oh please, please,” said Digory. “Could we get on?
The Lion’s getting further and further away.
And I do want to speak to him so dreadfully( 非常 ) badly.”
“Look here, Strawberry,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “This young gentleman has something on his mind that he wants to talk to the Lion about;
him you call Aslan. Suppose you were to let him ride on your back (which he’d take it very kindly) and trot( 小跑 ) him over to where the Lion is.
And me and the little girl will be following along.”
“Ride?” said Strawberry. “Oh, I remember now.
That means sitting on my back.
I remember there used to be a little one of you two-leggers who used to do that long ago.
He used to have little hard, square lumps( 块 ) of some white stuff( 东西 ) that he gave me.
They tasted—oh, wonderful, sweeter than grass.”
“Ah, that’d be sugar,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ).
“Please, Strawberry,” begged Digory, “do, do let me get up and take me to Aslan.”
“Well, I don’t mind,” said the Horse. “Not for once in a way. Up you get.”
“Good old Strawberry,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “Here, young one, I’ll give you a lift.” Digory was soon on Strawberry’s back, and quite comfortable,
for he had ridden bare( 裸露的 )-back before on his own pony( 小马驹 ).
“Now, do gee up, Strawberry,” he said.
“You don’t happen to have a bit of that white stuff( 东西 ) about you, I suppose?” said the Horse.
“No. I’m afraid I haven’t,” said Digory.
“Well, it can’t be helped,” said Strawberry, and off they went.
At that moment a large Bulldog( 斗牛犬 ), who had been sniffing( 嗅 ) and staring very hard, said:
“Look. Isn’t there another of these queer( 奇怪的 ) creatures—over there, beside the river, under the trees?”
Then all the animals looked and saw Uncle Andrew, standing very still among the rhododendrons( 杜鹃花 ) and hoping he wouldn’t be noticed.

“Come on!” said several voices. “Let’s go and find out.” So, while Strawberry was briskly( 轻快地 ) trotting( 小跑 ) away with Digory in one direction (and Polly and the Cabby( 马车夫 ) were following on foot) most of the creatures rushed toward Uncle Andrew with roars( 吼叫声 ), barks, grunts( 哼声 ), and various noises of cheerful interest.
We must now go back a bit and explain what the whole scene had looked like from Uncle Andrew’s point of view.
It had not made at all the same impression on him as on the Cabby( 马车夫 ) and the children.
For what you see and hear depends a good deal on where you are standing: it also depends on what sort of person you are.
Ever since the animals had first appeared, Uncle Andrew had been shrinking( 退缩 ) further and further back into the thicket( 灌木丛 ).
He watched them very hard of course; but he wasn’t really interested in seeing what they were doing,
only in seeing whether they were going to make a rush at him.
Like the Witch( 女巫 ), he was dreadfully( 非常地 ) practical.
He simply didn’t notice that Aslan was choosing one pair out of every kind of beasts.
All he saw, or thought he saw, was a lot of dangerous wild animals walking vaguely( 茫然地 ) about.
And he kept on wondering why the other animals didn’t run away from the big Lion.

article_info.previous: 随着狮子的歌唱，这片土地被赋予了生机。一群群动物涌现在他们眼前，狮子挑选了其中一些动物，赐予它们说话的能力，名叫“草莓”的那匹马也被选中。

article_info.share_words: Then all the animals looked and saw Uncle Andrew, standing very still among the rhododendrons and hoping he wouldn’t be noticed.

analysis: 根据之前的内容，狮子的歌声为这个世界带来各类动植物，是狮子建立了这个名为纳尼亚的世界，所以选C。

question.cn: 为什么Digory一定要和狮子说话？
question.en: Why must Digory speak to the Lion?

options.cn: 因为他认为狮子可以救他妈妈。
options.en: Because he thought the Lion could save his mother.

options.cn: 因为他认为狮子可以给他钱。
options.en: Because he thought the Lion could give him money.

options.cn: 因为他认为狮子可以带他回现实世界。
options.en: Because he thought the Lion could take him back to the real world.

analysis: 文中Digory说道：“ ‘I’ve got to,’ said Digory. ‘it’s about Mother. If anyone could give me something that would do her good, it would be him.’ ”由此得知Digory想要和狮子说话的原因是因为Digory认为他可以治好自己的妈妈，因此选A。

question.cn: 当Digory走向动物时，动物们正在干什么呢？
question.en: When Digory went towards the animals, what were these animals doing？

options.en: They were talking and making friends.

analysis: 文中提到：“So all three of them stepped out boldly-or as boldly as they could-toward the assembly of animals. They creatures were busy talking to another and making friends. . . ”由此可知，当Digory一行人走近动物群的时候，他们正忙着交谈和交朋友，因此选B。
文中马车夫说道：“This young gentleman has something on his mind that he wants to talk to the Lion about; him you call Aslan.”由此可知，狮子的名字叫Aslan，因此选A。

question.cn: “草莓”是否同意驮着Digory去赶上狮子？
question.en: Did the horse Strawberry agree to give Digory a ride?

analysis: 文中提到：“‘Please, Strawberry,’ begged Digory, ‘do, do let me get up and take me to Aslan.’ ‘Well, I don’t mind,’ said the Horse. ‘Not for once in a way. Up you get.’”由此可见，“草莓”同意驮着Digory去找狮子，因此本题选A。
